p: Variation in the cover and height of P. pumila is closely related to the degree of wind exposure and snow depth in high mountains during winter, together with microtopographic change. The height of P. pumila decreases gradually as the degree of wind exposure increases [ 40]. The degree of wind exposure is higher closer to the ridgeline on the wind-blown slope side in winter [ 41]. Thus, distance from the ridgeline was measured as the topographic factor that is considered to affect the height of the P. pumila community.
